none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from James E. Binkley, June 16, 1878
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from James E. Binkley, June 16, 1878
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: A deeply personal letter from James E. Binkley to his friend Louis L. McInnis, written from Columbus, Texas in June 1878, describing the tragic drowning death of Binkley's young son, Freddie. The letter captures Binkley's profound grief as he returns home to support his father while dealing with the loss of his child, whose body is initially missing in the river before being discovered and buried. Binkley requests that McInnis submit examination marks for his Algebra coursework and handle administrative matters at the college during his extended absence.

body.value:
[Header: Embossed stamp of U.S. Capitol Building with text "CONGRESS"]

Columbus, Texas,
June 16", 1878

Friend M:

Though I feel very little like
writing yet I must tell you the condition
I am in, and the feelings I experience.
This can be nothing more than a note.
The trains connected in Houston, and I ar-
rived safely at home yesterday at 2:10
P.M. As I anticipated I found my
father in the wildest state of excite-
ment, and the deepest throes of sorrow's
agony. 'Twas with the greatest effort
of my life that I controlled my
overflowing grief sufficiently to become
a comforter to him. Ah! me, I may
comfort him to some extent; myself to
none. Grief is my portion & grief
I must bear. My little boy's body
is still in the river, or - but I'll

My mission is clear: I'm transcribing handwritten text from an image, and I need to do so *precisely*. I have to maintain the original spelling, punctuation, and, critically, the line breaks as they appear in the image. I'm also expected to identify and label structural elements like headers and preserve the layout. I'm working with HTML tags, specifically `p` for paragraphs and `
` for line breaks and possibly `img` if there is an image. Next up, I'm analyzing the image. It's a handwritten letter, that much is obvious. I'm scanning for clues: there's an embossed stamp, which I'll note as a header; a date and location at the top-right; the salutation "Friend M"; and the body of the letter. The handwriting is 19th-century cursive, fairly legible, thankfully. Now for the line-by-line transcription. I'm mentally mapping the image to text. The embossed stamp is a U.S. Capitol building, and I need to note the text, which appears to be "CONGRESS." The date/location needs to be transcribed, being careful to note the comma and quote mark of "June 16"". The salutation is next. The "M" is a bit tricky, and I'll need to use context to get that right. The body seems to be about someone returning home after a journey and a family tragedy. I'm focusing on the words, but also on the *structure* of the text. I'm now refining and formatting. Because the guidelines emphasize maintaining layout, preserving the line breaks is essential. I'm planning to use `
` tags at the end of each physical line within paragraphs to ensure the transcript mirrors the original. The header needs labeling, the date and location needs to be handled as a distinct paragraph, and the salutation also needs its own line. I have to read the text carefully to make sure my interpretation is correct. The context tells me "Friend M" is likely a name or initial, and I'm going to represent the punctuation as best as possible. The ampersand is straightforward, apostrophes are key, and the dash needs to be preserved. Now to craft the HTML structure. I'm starting with a `

` tag for the header, noting the embossed stamp. The date/location goes into its own `

` block, using `
` to maintain the line breaks. The salutation gets its own paragraph as well. The main body of the letter gets the bulk of my attention, again, using `
` to replicate the original line breaks. Finally, I'm performing a final review. I have to ensure I've only used the permitted HTML tags. Spelling? Check. Line order? Check. Handwriting interpretation? I'm confident I have it correct. Structural labeling? Added. Now I generate the output, confident that I've followed the instructions precisely.

not speak of it - horrible thought! They
have vainly sought the dear child, though
now lifeless, in every place & manner.

I feel like a man adrift, yet I know
I'm not friendless. In this I will send
the xamination marks of my Algebra,
please hand them in submitting the
necessary remarks. Should it so happen
that you leave before my return dont
forget to give the Key to the Prest.

I would return the last of this
week, but cannot if matters remain
as they now are.

I know that you appreciate my
feelings enough to think nothing wrong
of this feeble attempt at composing
a letter. Give my regards to the
Profs., especially our Prest. Be likewise
a medium through which I may send
best wishes, &c. to Mrs G. & the young
ladies. Enough for the present,

[Signature]
Bindley

**Analysis of the Handwritten Letter** I've been tasked with transcribing this handwritten letter, and my initial thought is the somber nature of the opening. It starts mid-sentence, the subject matter is clearly distressing: "not speak of it - horrible thought! They have vainly sought the dear child, though now lifeless..." The "They" likely refers to others desperately searching for a deceased child. I feel a profound sense of loss, like a man adrift, but I also find solace in knowing I'm not entirely alone. I intend to send you the "xamination" marks from my Algebra. I'm hoping you can review them and provide the necessary feedback. I'm unsure when I'll be able to return, but if you're leaving before my return, please make sure to give the Key to the President (or perhaps the Priest, or a Professor; "Prest." is a very common 19th-century abbreviation). I had hoped to be back this week, but that's impossible given the situation. I trust you understand my feelings, that you don't think it wrong that I'm attempting this letter. Please give my regards to the Professors, particularly our President. I'm hoping you can act as a medium through which I can send my best wishes and so forth to Mrs. G and the young ladies. I'll conclude for now,

[Signature]
Bindley

Tuesday the 18" - On the day of finishing the
above note Freddie's body was found
in the river about fifteen miles below
here. 'Twas in a frightful condition,
but we managed to get him home
and properly interred. The burial
occurred yesterday morning at 10 oclock
No notices of a funeral were dis-
tributed but many persons were
out to witness the burial of my
boy - then idolized, now I hope angeliz-
ed. Father seems better reconciled
since the recovery & burial of his
little boy

'Twill be the last of next week
before I can return to the college,
then to remain not long. If you
know of anything you want of
me let me know by letter, or
if it comes to your mind too
late for that leave me a note
on our table

Singley

**A Transcriptionist's Process**

Alright, let's break this down. As a seasoned transcriptionist, my mind immediately goes into a structured mode. First, I'm setting the stage: I'm transcribing handwritten text from an image, aiming for accuracy and adherence to specific HTML tagging rules. No markdown tables here; plain, IIIF-compliant HTML.

Now, I'm analyzing the image. It's a cursive, handwritten letter—likely from the late 19th or early 20th century, given the style. I note the faded ink, the lined paper, and the way the text is split but continuous. The goal here is to get every nuance of the writing as precisely as possible.

Then, the nitty-gritty: a line-by-line transcription. I am treating the "18"" as an abbreviation of the 18th. Also, it's definitely "oclock," not "o'clock." The ampersand in "recovery & burial" is kept, of course. Hyphenation at the end of the line, like "angeliz-," will be maintained. A note that the word "comes" is definitely the intended word. The signature, after careful comparison of the letters, is most likely to be "Singley".

Formatting with HTML follows, wrapping paragraphs and adding line breaks to mirror the visual layout. The whole process is about fidelity. Finally, double-checking everything. The final output is ready: clean, accurate, and faithful to the original.

Crucially, *there is no visible text*. This is a blank sheet of paper, likely the back of a letter or from a notebook. Do I just return an empty response? Should I use a standard notation like "[Blank page]" or "[No text]"? The guidelines also tell me to label structural elements. I'm going to mark the stamp. **Implementation and Refinement** Let's test this. Since there's no legible text, the transcription is essentially empty, or just descriptive tags. I'll stick to a more generic description. **Final Solution** So, the stamp is in the top right, and it's a blank page. The safest approach is this: ```html
